results.abstract: Article on exhibit of 40 GI Joe doll-size figures, one for year years of his life, at Intrepid-Sea-Air-Space Museum; display borrowed from collectors and Hasbro, toy company that has produced all of more than 500 versions of Joe; Susan Marenoff, Intrepid's exhibit coordinator, comments; photo (M)

headline.main: One Old Soldier Who Won't Fade Away

results.snippet: HE -- and with a couple of exceptions, he always was a he -- is hitting the big Four-Oh. He is the doll-size figure that swaggered into the American consciousness in his battle fatigues in 1964, the year that Ford Mustang, Diet Pepsi and Kellogg's...
results.lead_paragraph: HE -- and with a couple of exceptions, he always was a he -- is hitting the big Four-Oh. He is the doll-size figure that swaggered into the American consciousness in his battle fatigues in 1964, the year that Ford Mustang, Diet Pepsi and Kellogg's Pop-Tarts also joined consumers' vocabularies. Now G.I. Joe, whose toy-store life began as a kind of Barbie for boys, is old enough to be a collectible. And with prices ranging from $75 to more than $4,000 for a rare 1967 figure in mint condition, old Joes are less likely to be played with than stared at under museum-quality lighting.

results.abstract: Jennifer Moses travel essay on nearly impossible task of trying to instill love of culture in her young children; focuses on visits to Europe; drawing (M)

headline.main: Is Culture Wasted on the Very Young?

results.snippet: BEFORE my husband, Stuart, and I actually became parents of real live children, we were certain that, by the time our offspring were of school age, they'd be on loving terms with everything from Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons'' to T.S. Eliot's ''Four...
results.lead_paragraph: BEFORE my husband, Stuart, and I actually became parents of real live children, we were certain that, by the time our offspring were of school age, they'd be on loving terms with everything from Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons'' to T.S. Eliot's ''Four Quartets.'' We pictured jaunts with our angelic sweethearts to various cultural meccas -- Florence, Paris -- where our shared experience of the glories of art would bring us that much closer. Then real life hit in the form of our firstborn, Sam, and all our romantic ideas went kerplop. True, for some years before his twin sister and brother were born, Sam liked nothing better than to pull all our books off the shelves -- he was eager, my husband said, to read our complete ''Remembrance of Things Past''. And, in an attempt to be tourists in our own backyard -- at that time Washington, D.C. -- we spent countless Saturdays at the Smithsonian.

results.abstract: Group of international astronomers, studying massive black hole in neighboring M87 galaxy, says black hole is emitting tone different from black hole in Perseus cluster, which was recently identified as giving off b-flat tone, 57 octaves below middle C; Dr William Forman of Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics and member of reseach team explains theory on how black holes gain and project masses of energy, which impact sound of black hole; Dr Anton Koekemoer of Baltimore's Space Telescope Science Institute describes black hole as spider-like entity, that while awaiting prey emits steady tone, but after eating gives off bursts of energy and variant sound waves; photos (S)

headline.main: Songs of the Galaxies, and What They Mean

results.snippet: Another black hole is singing, although it seems a little tone-deaf.    Last year, astronomers discovered that outbursts from a giant black hole were spreading pressure waves through the thin hot gas of the distant Perseus cluster of galaxies. The...
results.lead_paragraph: Another black hole is singing, although it seems a little tone-deaf. Last year, astronomers discovered that outbursts from a giant black hole were spreading pressure waves through the thin hot gas of the distant Perseus cluster of galaxies. The frequency of these waves was equivalent to a B flat, 57 octaves below middle C, the astronomers calculated.

results.abstract: 9Live, call-in quiz channel, is Germany's fastest-growing television broadcaster; viewers pay about 49 euro cents (60 cents) a call to participate in station's live quiz shows; station splits revenues from calls with Deutsche Telekom; is owned by Euvia Media, whose controlling shareholder is InterActiveCorp; photo (M)

headline.main: German Quiz Shows Thrive As Contestants Stay Home

results.snippet: The smiling quiz-show host, a former singer with a German boy band, stares into the TV camera and directs the caller to unscramble a four-word clue: Atle Lebie Sotret Nicth.    ''Alte Liebe rostet nicht,'' answers Brigitte, on the phone from southern...
results.lead_paragraph: The smiling quiz-show host, a former singer with a German boy band, stares into the TV camera and directs the caller to unscramble a four-word clue: Atle Lebie Sotret Nicth. ''Alte Liebe rostet nicht,'' answers Brigitte, on the phone from southern Germany. ''Old love doesn't rust.''

results.abstract: Admr Sean O'Keefe says NASA moves ahead with plan to send robot to extend life of Hubble Space Telescope; says decision on mission will not be made until next summer; plans to ask Congress for financing, estimated to cost $1 billion to $1.6 billion (S)

headline.main: Plan for Robot to Fix Telescope Advances

results.snippet: NASA is moving ahead with plans to send a robot to the rescue of the Hubble Space Telescope, the agency's administrator, Sean O'Keefe, said on Tuesday.      The leading candidate is a two-armed device named Dextre that bears little resemblance to...
results.lead_paragraph: NASA is moving ahead with plans to send a robot to the rescue of the Hubble Space Telescope, the agency's administrator, Sean O'Keefe, said on Tuesday. The leading candidate is a two-armed device named Dextre that bears little resemblance to movie-inspired visions of a robot.

results.abstract: Threat of terror may seem imminent in summer of 2004, but solutions to US intelligence failings, as documented in 9/11 Commission report, will take years to carry out (M)

headline.main: The World; Intelligence: Why a Fix Is So Elusive

results.snippet: THE Olympics have opened in Greece, carrying with it fears of a replay of the event that opened the era of televised, large-scale terror: the 1972 Munich attack. Madison Square Garden, the site of the Republican National Convention, is so tempting a...
results.lead_paragraph: THE Olympics have opened in Greece, carrying with it fears of a replay of the event that opened the era of televised, large-scale terror: the 1972 Munich attack. Madison Square Garden, the site of the Republican National Convention, is so tempting a target that Midtown Manhattan will be sealed off in ways never seen, even in the first days after Sept. 11. And in Washington, there is so much talk of the ''pre-election threat'' that a senior White House official was insisting to reporters on Thursday that Election Day will go forward no matter what Osama bin Laden may be contemplating to influence the outcome.

results.abstract: Article on rock climbing adventure with three young sons at Great Wall climbing and guiding center at Sundial Boutique Hotel in Whistler, British Columbia (M)
results.snippet: IN rock climbing, the belay rope is your umbilical cord. If you lose your balance, pull loose rock or just freeze in utter terror midway up, you have to trust that your partner on the ground holding the other end of the rope (and your life) in his...
results.lead_paragraph: IN rock climbing, the belay rope is your umbilical cord. If you lose your balance, pull loose rock or just freeze in utter terror midway up, you have to trust that your partner on the ground holding the other end of the rope (and your life) in his hands, will check your fall. On belay, trust is what allows you to hang from three fingers grasping a hair-wide crack of rock while your feet flail about, searching for the slightest purchase. Conquering your natural fear of falling requires calling up stores of faith you never knew existed. Unless you're one of my children.

results.abstract: Dr James E Alleman of Purdue University and colleagues research and develop ways to recycle urine and feces into plant fertilizer and clean water for astronauts on extended space mission; basic process described (M)

headline.main: On Mars, More Water From Pricey Plumbing

results.snippet: When NASA decides to send astronauts to Mars and farther out, one of the biggest technological hurdles it will face will be making sure they don't get thirsty.    A $49,000 toilet at Purdue University may provide part of the answer.
results.lead_paragraph: When NASA decides to send astronauts to Mars and farther out, one of the biggest technological hurdles it will face will be making sure they don't get thirsty. A $49,000 toilet at Purdue University may provide part of the answer.

results.abstract: Profile of and interview with Russian clown Slava Polunin, whose show Slava's Snowshoe will make its New York premiere on Sept 8 at Union Square Theater; photo (M)

headline.main: A Late-Summer Blizzard Hits East 17th Street

results.snippet: IN Siberia last January, the Russian clown Slava Polunin had to declare two tons of snow at the airport. ''I brought the snow from Paris,'' he said recently. ''When customs agents check the lists of the things I'm bringing with me, they always laugh....
results.lead_paragraph: IN Siberia last January, the Russian clown Slava Polunin had to declare two tons of snow at the airport. ''I brought the snow from Paris,'' he said recently. ''When customs agents check the lists of the things I'm bringing with me, they always laugh. It's written down on the customs form: 'moon, wind, rainbow, stars.' '' Snow made of paper? Stars made of glitter? ''No!'' he insisted. ''I only have magical things in my show. You can't explain what it's made of. I have real snow, real wind, real stars.''
